hero.title: The Bitcoin Standard Explorer
hero.subtitle: The Decentralized Alternative For Central Banking
hero.description: An interactive guide to the principles, arguments, and ideas behind Saifedean Ammous's groundbreaking book.
hero.note: Only chapter 1-6 are up to date.

chapter1.title: Money
chapter1.summary: The first chapter introduces the concept of money and its evolution throughout history. Ammous explains that money is a tool for moving economic value across time and space. The most important property of money is its hardness - the difficulty to produce more of it. Throughout history, societies that used hard money (difficult to produce) prospered, while those using easy money declined.
chapter1.takeaway: Sound money is essential for civilization to flourish, as it encourages low time preference and capital accumulation.

chapter2.title: Primitive Money
chapter2.summary: This chapter explores how early forms of money emerged from barter systems. Various objects served as money in different societies, but they all shared certain properties: durability, divisibility, portability, and most importantly, salability (ease of selling). The hardest forms of primitive money were those most difficult to produce, like seashells and beads.
chapter2.takeaway: Money naturally emerges in societies as the most salable good, and the hardest money tends to win out over time.

chapter3.title: Monetary Metals
chapter3.summary: Metals became the dominant form of money due to their superior physical properties. Gold emerged as the prime monetary metal because of its extreme scarcity and difficulty to produce. The gold standard allowed for unprecedented economic growth and stability in the 19th century, as it imposed fiscal discipline on governments and encouraged saving and capital accumulation.
chapter3.takeaway: Gold became the global standard for money because of its unmatched stock-to-flow ratio, making it the hardest form of money available.

chapter4.title: Government Money
chapter4.summary: The 20th century saw the shift from sound money (gold) to government-controlled fiat currencies. This transition began with World War I when governments needed to finance war efforts. The Bretton Woods system (1944-1971) attempted to maintain gold's discipline while giving governments monetary control, but ultimately failed when the US abandoned gold convertibility in 1971.
chapter4.takeaway: The shift from gold to fiat currency removed natural constraints on government spending and monetary expansion.

chapter5.title: Money and Time Preference
chapter5.summary: This pivotal chapter explains how the type of money a society uses affects time preference - the degree to which people value present consumption over future consumption. Hard money (like gold or Bitcoin) encourages low time preference, meaning people are more willing to delay gratification and invest for the future. Soft money (like fiat currencies) encourages high time preference and present consumption.
chapter5.takeaway: The hardness of money directly influences societal time preference, which shapes everything from personal choices to civilization's advancement.

chapter6.title: Capitalism's Information System
chapter6.summary: Sound money serves as an accurate information system for capital allocation in free markets. Price signals in a hard money system reflect real consumer preferences and resource scarcity. Under inflationary fiat systems, this signaling mechanism becomes distorted, leading to boom-bust cycles and malinvestment.
chapter6.takeaway: Sound money is essential for capitalism to function properly as it provides accurate price signals for efficient resource allocation.

chapter7.title: Sound Money and Individual Freedom
chapter7.summary: This chapter explores how sound money limits government power and enhances individual freedom. When governments control money creation, they can finance activities without direct taxation, expanding beyond what citizens would voluntarily support. Sound money acts as a check on government growth and protects individual property rights.
chapter7.takeaway: Sound money is a prerequisite for individual freedom as it limits government's ability to expropriate wealth through inflation.

chapter8.title: Digital Money
chapter8.summary: The final chapters examine Bitcoin as the first truly digital form of sound money. Bitcoin solves the double-spending problem through its decentralized consensus mechanism and has a perfectly predictable supply schedule. Its digital nature gives it advantages over gold in terms of verifiability and transferability, while maintaining the crucial property of hardness.
chapter8.takeaway: Bitcoin represents the first digital implementation of sound money principles, combining gold's scarcity with superior transferability and divisibility.

chapter9.title: What Is Bitcoin Good For?
chapter9.summary: This chapter analyzes Bitcoin's potential use cases. Its primary value proposition is as a store of value and settlement network, rather than for small daily transactions. Bitcoin offers a neutral, borderless monetary system outside government control, making it particularly valuable for international settlements, wealth preservation, and as protection against financial repression.
chapter9.takeaway: Bitcoin's most important function is as digital sound money - a store of value free from government control and debasement.

chapter10.title: Bitcoin Questions
chapter10.summary: The final chapter addresses common criticisms and questions about Bitcoin. It explains why Bitcoin's energy consumption is justified by its value proposition, why its fixed supply isn't problematic, and how it compares to other cryptocurrencies. Ammous argues that Bitcoin's first-mover advantage and network effects make it unlikely to be replaced by competitors.
chapter10.takeaway: Bitcoin's unique combination of properties makes it the only truly sound digital money, with significant advantages over both traditional currencies and other cryptocurrencies.

concepts.title: Concept Explorer
concepts.description: Explore the key concepts from The Bitcoin Standard and how they relate to each other. Hover over nodes to see brief descriptions and click for more detailed explanations.

hardMoney.title: Hard Money
hardMoney.tooltip: Money that's difficult to produce or inflate
hardMoney.explanation: Hard money is currency that is difficult to produce or inflate. Throughout history, societies using hard money (like gold) have prospered because it encourages saving and investment. Bitcoin is the hardest money ever created due to its fixed supply of 21 million coins.

lowTimePreference.title: Low Time Preference
lowTimePreference.tooltip: Valuing future rewards over immediate gratification
lowTimePreference.explanation: Low time preference means valuing future rewards over immediate gratification. When money holds its value, people are more likely to save and invest for the long term rather than consume immediately. This mindset is essential for building civilization and technological progress.

capitalAccumulation.title: Capital Accumulation
capitalAccumulation.tooltip: Building productive resources through saving and investment
capitalAccumulation.explanation: Capital accumulation is the process of building productive resources through saving and investment. When people save under a hard money standard, these savings can be channeled into productive investments that increase society's wealth and productive capacity over time.

civilizationGrowth.title: Civilization Growth
civilizationGrowth.tooltip: Advancement of society through innovation and prosperity
civilizationGrowth.explanation: Civilization growth refers to the advancement of human society through technological innovation, cultural development, and increased prosperity. Hard money and low time preference create the conditions for capital accumulation, which provides the resources necessary for long-term projects that advance civilization.

softMoney.title: Soft Money
softMoney.tooltip: Money that's easy to produce or inflate
softMoney.explanation: Soft money is currency that is easy to produce or inflate. Fiat currencies controlled by governments are examples of soft money, as their supply can be increased at will. Soft money tends to lose value over time, discouraging saving and encouraging consumption.

inflation.title: Inflation
inflation.tooltip: Expansion of money supply leading to rising prices
inflation.explanation: Inflation is the expansion of money supply leading to rising prices and diminishing purchasing power. When money is easy to create, authorities tend to increase its supply, causing inflation. This erodes savings and forces people to seek returns that outpace inflation rather than focusing on productive investments.

highTimePreference.title: High Time Preference
highTimePreference.tooltip: Valuing immediate gratification over future rewards
highTimePreference.explanation: High time preference means valuing immediate gratification over future rewards. When money loses value through inflation, people are incentivized to spend quickly rather than save. This short-term thinking leads to consumption over investment and undermines long-term planning.

economicDecay.title: Economic Decay
economicDecay.tooltip: Deterioration of economic systems through malinvestment
economicDecay.explanation: Economic decay is the deterioration of economic systems characterized by malinvestment, debt accumulation, and declining productivity. When high time preference dominates society, resources are consumed rather than invested productively, leading to economic stagnation and decline.

bitcoin.title: Bitcoin
bitcoin.tooltip: Decentralized digital currency with fixed supply
bitcoin.explanation: Bitcoin is the first and most secure decentralized digital currency, created in 2009. It has a fixed supply of 21 million coins, making it the hardest money ever created. Bitcoin combines the scarcity properties of gold with the transferability advantages of digital information.

digitalHardMoney.title: Digital Hard Money
digitalHardMoney.tooltip: Scarce digital currency resistant to debasement
digitalHardMoney.explanation: Digital hard money is currency that exists in digital form while maintaining the properties of hard money, particularly scarcity and resistance to debasement. Bitcoin pioneered this category by solving the double-spending problem through its blockchain technology, creating digital scarcity for the first time.

globalEconomicCoordination.title: Global Economic Coordination
globalEconomicCoordination.tooltip: Worldwide economic cooperation through neutral money
globalEconomicCoordination.explanation: Global economic coordination refers to the ability for economic actors worldwide to coordinate activities using a common monetary standard. Bitcoin enables this by providing a neutral, borderless monetary system that isn't controlled by any government or corporation, potentially allowing for more efficient global trade and investment.
